title: 106_hr5469
content: The Act titled "Integrity of the United States Courts Act of 2000" allows for judicial review of binational panel decisions under the North American Free Trade Agreement Implementation Act. The "Integrity of the United States Courts Act of 2000" permits judicial review of binational panel determinations under the North American Free Trade Agreement Implementation Act within 30 days of publication in the Federal Register. If a party alleges gross misconduct, bias, conflict of interest, procedural departure, or exceeding of powers by a panel member, they can seek review in the Court of International Trade. If a party alleges misconduct, bias, conflict of interest, procedural departure, or exceeding of powers by a binational panel under the North American Free Trade Agreement, they can file an appeal with the United States Court of International Trade within 30 days of publication in the Federal Register. If a party alleges misconduct, bias, conflict of interest, procedural departure, or exceeding of powers by a binational panel under the North American Free Trade Agreement, they can file an appeal with the United States Court of International Trade within 30 days of publication in the Federal Register. If the panel's decision materially affects the review process, an appeal can be made to the Court of International Trade for review. The court will examine the legal and factual analysis to determine if any misconduct has occurred. The Court of International Trade will review the findings and conclusions of a binational panel's decision to determine if any actions described have been established. If so, the original panel decision will be vacated, and judgment entered accordingly. Decisions made by the Court of International Trade are binding on the parties involved. The Court of International Trade has exclusive jurisdiction over appeals related to NAFTA goods. Decisions made by the Court are binding and not subject to review by an extraordinary challenge committee. The jurisdiction exclusively resides with the United States Court of International Trade for appeals related to NAFTA goods, and decisions made by the Court are not subject to review by an extraordinary challenge committee. This section applies to all goods from NAFTA countries subject to antidumping or countervailing duty determinations in the United States. SEC. 3. JURISDICTION OF THE COURT OF INTERNATIONAL TRADE. Review of binational panel determinations. Section 516A of the Tariff Act of 1930 is amended to include a final determination of a binational panel convened under NAFTA. The Tariff Act of 1930 is amended to include final determinations of binational panels under NAFTA, including specific provisions related to subsections (a)(5) and (g)(3)(A) of the Act. The Tariff Act of 1930 is amended to include final determinations of binational panels under NAFTA, with specific provisions related to section 404A of the North American Free Trade Agreement Implementation Act. The amendments made by this Act apply to final determinations of binational panels under NAFTA published in the Federal Register after the enactment date.
